title.narrative: AIM Georgia and Ukraine: Accountability through Independent Media

description.narrative:
Key results: The overall objective is well-informed and politically engaged public of all genders & civil society in Ukraine and Georgia hold duty-bearers to account:
1. Public interest content and Media: Independent and resilient public interest media are more viable and produce and disseminate ethical, gender-inclusive, diverse content and provide fora for constructive public debate online and offline.
2. Safety: Local safety mechanisms are available to protect media workers of all genders, mitigate the risks they face and address impunity both online and offline.
3. Enabling digital environment: Media sector in Georgia and Ukraine utilise technological advances for strengthening freedom of expression and public participation of all genders.
4. Synergy with Tech for Democracy initiatives: Increased focus on digital solution that promotes human rights, enhance people’s engagement, and make democratic institutions stronger and more responsive.
Justification for support: Georgia and Ukraine have struggled to democratise and pursue European integration in recent years, they face strong resistance from Russia and antidemocratic elements within their borders. Media and civil society are trying to find new ways of engaging in this complex environment which is influenced by political and economic instability and corruption. In both Ukraine and Georgia, the media is dominated by influential economic actors with strong interests in political power, and in Georgia, the largest media house have become part of political polarization. Ukraine’s infrastructure allows for production of abundant, varied, and quality content in all types of media, and technology has grown more affordable. The diversity of mainstream media owners provides a measure of pluralism, but the oligarchs that run the largest and most popular television channels are bent on shoring up their political and economic interests.
